comments.commentBody: Pellet guns hit rioters storming security officers assaulting them with rocks and even grenades! In USA they would have been shot dead by cops. It is sad that these misguided youth are wasting their precious lives in this manner
American's Predator Drones are better?
The use of these pellet guns are heart-breaking and criminal. So absolutely sad.

Artists whose work is political in nature (a hanging man image cast by Sichuan earthquake rubble) complaining on Twitter about politics seem disingenuous in their need for self-promotion.  Xiao Ai might be better served working with mirrors.

Mr. Krishnamachari, the curator, said “I strongly believe artists should have the freedom to do whatever they feel like, otherwise you can’t call it art.” The performance artist Donald Trump is exhibit-A of this dubious ideology.

Not all art pieces are about ideas, but many highfalutin ones are. Some ideas are noble, and some not so much.

Donald wows his loyal audience with whatever comes to his mind that suits his designs. There is no red-line. That's artist with the con- in front of it. But Trump does not operate in China, where censors draw the line for provocateurs. Ai Wei-Wei should move his exhibit to MOMA, a much more "fertile" ground for his masterpiece.
I wonder if Mr Ai's arts are only interested in politics?  Or maybe NYT is only interested in Chinese arts that are political?
Guy is more hype than anything else.

Artists are on the leading edge of social commentary and social change – often. Ai Weiwei lives there, though the message is sometime more in the words wrapped around the work than in its presentation. He used steel rods collected from the rubble of a devastating earthquake in Sichuan Province in 2008 to build a loosely construction display in the San Francisco De Young Museum of Art and the impact was in the enormous number of children who died under some of that debris, if you missed that fact you missed the message.
Interesting how little it took here to set the authorities off – a title.
It's cute to hear someone saying that they are speaking on behalf of 1.5 billion others.
Well, we've heard from Mr. Fifty Cents here - part of an army of paid online supporters of Party views.  Read with appropriate caution.

John sf......your first sentence, that no one in China likes Ai Wei Wei, is an untrustworthy and delusional opinion without any basis in fact.
To clarify your understanding,Ai,is an artist that searches for the "real"in the human condition without regard to '"east"and "west"or political philosophy...........his "Red Line"can symbolize the plutocrat communist elites in China that pretend to rule as the "proletariat masses".......or the capitalist "bottom line" of profit which defines the institutionalized opportunistic corruption of politics in the west.
The right to freely criticize your government(whose parameters are always changing) is essential to life,liberty and the pursuit of happiness........and to understand who is in charge!

Trust me, no one in China likes this dude. Even though I myself am critical of my own country, I still think of this man as a traitor of Chinese people. Seeking "assistance" from the West is simply not an option, and the US is never a "Savior". A "free" China will be nothing but a puppet state which realizes interest of the westerners. I assume this is also the stand of all educated Chinese.
Mr Ai is talented, creative and courageous. The CCP and its cronies are dull, unimaginative, and afraid. Who should the people support?

A tender film, thank you Ruby Yang; it all looks so familiar in a different setting, the center holds.
Good to see the information on the Norden Camp and that no Tibet Autonomous Region (T.A.R.) visa is required in that region of the Tibetan Plateau, but at 3200 meters attitude sickness could result for those not acclimatized on the way up. A backpackers dream.

@Jeff Stockwell
The problems you mentioned are not unique to China, examples abound in the USA as well. China in 2008 surpassed the US as the worlds leading polluter but comes no where close in per capita pollution levels. You want to make China out to be an unimaginable ogre and its prison environment may qualify but the seldom analyzed US private prison system is now coming into the headlines grimly. Both lead the world in death sentences. On mortality rates, US infant mortality rates are higher than those in 41 nations including China; the life span of the average person in China in 1950 was 40 years; by 2011 it was around 76. (The average life span in the United States in 2011 was 79.) Pew does comparisons of citizens attitudes, you might check those out and see who fairs best. Time perhaps to rewrite your assessments.
The Transplantation Society’s critique of China’s use of prisoner’s organs was formulated on lack of consent, but in all likelihoods was underlain by the knowledge that such practice will become a profit driven enterprise without constraints in a prison environment. Whether it has been abandoned needs inquire not just opinions. This article does not help much.

I don't think Falun Gong is a good thing. It just tries to use the religion as a mask to confront with the communist party. Neither of them are purely kind to normal people. Those adherents of Falun Gong who once burned themselves at Tiananmen Square are really innocent and poor! They think they are in the pursuit of good, truth and beauty but actually are made use by the leadership of Falun Gong and involved into a cruel political fight.

Thanks for posting this link.
A tiny chilling excerpt from the introduction:
"Chapter five set out statements of patients who went to China for transplants. These statements showed that organs were available on short notice, in secrecy, with a heavy involvement of military personnel and institutions.
Chapter six looked at Chinese transplant hospitals. Many of these hospitals on their websites actively promoted transplant tourism, advertising easy, quick availability of organs, at high prices.
Chapter seven detailed calls investigators made to hospitals. The callers pretended to be relatives of patients who needed transplants and asked for organs of practitioners of Falun Gong. The reason for the requests was that the exercises of practitioners meant the organs would be healthy. Hospitals throughout China told the callers, in calls which were taped, transcribed and translated, that they had organs of Falun Gong practitioners for sale."

It's been estimated that as many as 70 million Chinese practiced Falun Gong. If Falun Gong has become essentially "nonexistent", even if that episode was wrong by an order of magnitude, we are looking at a veritable holocaust, at least of those who, as you put it, "refused to recant." So, "off with their heads", so to speak. And away with their livers and lungs.
As far as the critique of Falun Gong, this in no way whatsoever excuses what was and apparently is a programmatic mass murder for human organs. Or do you suggest that the followers of Mary Baker Eddy are also worthy of dispatch for a mass organ transplant business?

Falun Gong indeed had practitioners on the order of tens of millions in China at that time. But the vast majority of them practised it in the hope of improving their health and would not cling onto it at the risk of going to jail. The percentage of hard core Falun Gong followers who hold it as a religious belief is extremely small. If I have to make a guess, I would say probably in the low tens of thousands all over China. It is very likely that many of them suffered various degree of abuse in police custody, and some of them died with organs taken for transplant. But I don't believe there could have been a coordinated effort nationwide to harvest the organs of Falun Gong followers, because no official, high or low, would ever want to be associated with a program of murder. Higher level officials have nothing to gain by coordinating such a program, only everything to lose. Whatever happened, could only have happened in the dark at the local level, for profits. The smaller the locality, the less the oversight, the more likely abuse took place.

Such profit driven abuse are not unique to China. In every developing country, whatever the form of Govt, there is various degree of corruption and abuse. It's just that for countries with authoritarian govts, it's easier to pin all the blame on the govt. That's why when abuse takes place in democratic third world countries, they attract much less western media attention, because there is no simple narrative as to whom to blame.

Of course, the Govt crackdown on Falun Gong allowed the possibility of large scale abuses. If it was another group that did not have the political taboo attached, there would have been more exposures of such abuses that act as a check.

Anyway, I'm not trying to excuse the detention, abuse, or even murder of Falun Gong followers, wherever they occurred. But the data is scarce and the facts are hard to pin down. In western media, there is a tendency to exaggerate because it fits the narrative of an evil authoritarian Govt. Just as people were eager to believe that Saddam Hussein hoarded weapons of mass destruction. But the reality is much more complex. The investigations cited statistics from some Chinese hospitals, and that hospital staff is ready to comply with patients' request for organs of Falun Gong practitioners. But why should one just trust what they say, when they have an incentive to lie to attract business? The bottom line is that, without reliable data, it is simply not possible to draw strong conclusions. If anyone claims otherwise, then one should be skeptical.

The crackdown on Falun Gong was almost two decades ago. Within China, Falun Gong has become essentially non-existent, and it will be hard to find prisoners currently jailed because of practising Falun Gong. So the treatment of Falun Gong practitioners, and whether there were systematic harvesting of their organs, concerns the past, and is kept alive because some Falun Gong followers overseas remain active.

Chinese political system is highly centralised, but it's also very difficult to enforce laws and orders uniformly across the country, especially when it conflicts with local interests. It's extremely unlikely that the central Govt would order or even condone harvesting of organs of Falun Gong practitioners because of the potential international outcry. However, at the local level, there is economic incentive to profit from organ harvesting on death-row inmates, and conceivably also die-hard Falun Gong followers who would not recant.

Lastly, it should be pointed out that Falun Gong does have certain cult like features. It was one of many different meditation sects in China at that time, called Qi Gong, which supposedly help circulate Qi in the body and cure one's own, as well as other people's illness, even terminal illness. It is a mix of meditation and religion. Unlike other Qi Gong, Falun Gong is more exclusive and forbids its followers from practicing any other form of Qi Gong. Followers are also advised against seeing doctors for illness.

Readers, follow the link. I posted a few chilling paragraphs from the intro, which the NY Times apparently suppressed. I presume that the Times can expect to be hacked by the Chinese, by way of retaliation for this story.
The excerpts I posted were not gory, but their implications were stomach turning nevertheless. This is a deep deep black mark against one of earth's oldest civilizations, that will go down in history alongside the "final solution" in its heinousness, even if not comparable in absolute number of victims. As if numbers are of any value at all when considering such a nadir of human behavior.
Could you please suggest any other means to disperse violent crowd decided to kill security personals ?
Horrible!  What else can I say!

An editorial in The Economist (current edition) suggests that not only are central banks targeting too low an inflation rate (2%), but that the present situation argues for a different target altogether: a growth rate target in nominal, not real, GDP. Paralleling earlier arguments by Dr Krugman, they suggest that markets need to believe that they're serious about such targets, in order for investment to occur that would then enable sufficiently high interest rates without threatening growth -- and thus putting the financial system in better shape to deal with the next recession.

I'd be interested to read Dr Krugman's reaction to The Economist's suggestion.
After recent decriminalization legislation in Colorado, I think it's very likely that Wyoming is a squarer state! :)
Dale McIntyre --- I fear you have been Curried.   Try reading Ray Pierrehumbert's book instead.

Ali, thanks for the good grammar. People, "the" Dry Tortugas "are" plural, despite the article.

I appreciate learning (by reading) what it means when a pirate in a story mentions "the Dry Tortugas". I never knew. It's fascinating, and the importance of the dessicated Dry Tortugas to pirates (in fiction, at least) also suggests that pirating wasn't a great occupation.
"Preserved"?

Any munition fired from a weapon that uses a gunpowder-like propellant is capable of delivering serious injuries. The Israelis and I believe the British during the Troubles were taken to task for their use of "rubber bullets" which were basically large metal cylinders covered in hard rubber and later I believe switched to plastic. These leave the barrel had hundreds of feet per second and can break bones or even cause death; the protocol is to bounce them off the ground, but as you imagine they get fired at a parallel to ground trajectory hitting people straight on.

For pure crowd dispersion, tear gas seems a better option. If they really need to fire projectiles, paintball-type weapons with a pepper-spray filled projectiles would be less dangerous while having a greater deterrent effect. They'd have a greater useful range, too, allowing the security forces a standoff distance that might allow for de-escalation.

Just to add...see where those migrants are now. The people who came to India got all the rights people already living here had. I don't see any discrimination whatsoever. Now look at Pakistan. Even after 70 years, the Muslim migrants are called "Mohajirs" and still treated constitutionally as second class citizens.

My parents also migrated from India to Pakistan in the mayhem and hell that was the partition on the other end of the sub continent. However the same does not apply to Kashmiris. They live on their own land. No one can tell them to leave.
India feels it has the firepower to suppress a large population indefinitely. This is definitely the logic behind more than half century of violence against the Kashmiris. Conscience however is missing from this argument.

Let's separate two things here.

First, Indian troops should stop using shotguns and resort to using rubber bullets to control stone-throwing crowds, and escalate the violence only proportionately. As usual, the foolish babus in South Block do not understand how they lose the battle for media sympathy. The jihadis in Kashmir will use women and children in the front lines in same manner as ISIS.

Second, all the Paksitani sympathizers should understand that the chances of India ceding any part of J&K territory to Pakistan to an independent state is about as real as the South successfully seceding again from the United States. Wars have been fought and won over Kashmir. It does not matter a whit what Muslims in the Valley feel about independence, having driven the Hindus out of the Valley to refugee camps in Jammu and elsewhere. The only way Kashmir will ever be independent is by the destruction of the Indian nation state. I wouldn't hold my breath on that possibility.

After Partition in 1947, million of Muslims and Hindus left their land and moved across the border. The families of both my father and mother were among those refugees. If Kashmiri Muslims are so unhappy in India's rule in Kashmir, they should just pack up and leave, just like my grandparents did from East Pakistan and moved to India.

The "anniversary" of an event depends on what calendar one observes.  The September 11 attacks, if one uses the Islamic calendar, do not have their anniversary on September 11 in the Roman Catholic Gregorian calendar -- which,  whether you're a Catholic or not, is the basis of what we think of as the secular calendar.  Same difference with the Chinese calendar, the Persian calendar, the Jewish calendar, the Hindu calendar.  This could be a teachable moment about calendars, their dependence on the phases of the moon and the apparent motion of the sun through the constellations -- and the fact that all human dating systems are arbitrary.

I think most of the world's leaders like to talk a lot of road accidents and meaninglessly
Canceling road accidents is not Difficult to do because a similar system currently works in the agricultural sector.
Agricultural system is more complex than necessary to the traffic system.
So you can run the traffic system immediately.
I'm talking about using Precision Farming to Solve problems in Precision Traffic.
Mathematical examination of the passage shows that the Precision traffic less complex than Precision Farming from the known rule that in the surface there are infinite lines.
The Precision traffic system educates and instills a driving culture.
Precision traffic system reduces the time length of learning to dimensions of months.
Perhaps the allegations true, or perhaps the allegations are false. There is no way to know when the Chinese government operates like a black box: with zero transprency and zero accountability.

I'll never forgive commenters for injecting simple-minded, thinly veiled, poorly informed bigotry into intelligent debate. It wastes not only time but the obviousness of its refutation is automatically lost on anyone who would aver it in the first place.
